title: Are there any famous singers now who rely on auto tune most of the time? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. All currently famous singers have absolute vocal integrity. With the obvious exception of Drake, Ariana Grande, Lady Gaga, Mac Miller, Katy Perry, Beyoncé, Taylor Swift, Drake, Ed Sheeran, Sean Combs, Eminem, Kelly Clarkson, Selena Gomez, Carrie Underwood, Pink, Mariah Carey, John Legend, The Weeknd, Madonna, Miley Cyrus, Jennifer Lopez, Christina Aguilera, Will Smith, Ellie Goulding, Adam Levine, Jay-Z, Hilary Duff, Keith Urban, Gwen Stefani, Robbie Williams, Michael Bublé, Robin Thicke, Paul McCartney, Iggy Azalea, Alicia Keys, Katharine McPhee, Bruno Mars, Charli XCX, Celine Dion, Lana Del Rey, Tyler The Creator, Tyga, Shakira, Harry Styles, Ne-Yo, Logic, and roughly two hundred thousand lesser vocalists.

This question is a Trojan Horse. Auto-tune is a studio device (it can be used live only with a lot of effort). Like every technological advance since the electrical microphone, it is not so much a ”cheat” as it is a welcome nuance that can enhance the track). In my second Columbia album, I had a song that was almost perfect…only the singer was slightly sharp throughout the whole thing. After many takes, I ended up settling for a less-than-elegant solution by drowning her in echo. I think studio techniques have bypassed the older models, and that we need to incorporate the new into our spatial concepts.

Most of them use it on their recorded tracks. And not for the obvious adjustments to pitch because of poor singing ability like you might think. Instead it allows them to adjust pitch in creative ways for a more interesting sounds. I have a terrific video I wish I could share here. Comparing recorded and live vocals side by side. If you want to find it it’s on WTFacts channel. I found it searching Autotuned Vs Real Voice of Famous Singers.

Yes. Most singers today have some kind of pitch correction software used on their vocal tracks. Not so much because they’re not good singers as much as because it’s the sound of most of today’s popular music. You’ll rarely hear any even slightly off key vocal parts in today’s music
